program_name: Xcel Energy Colorado Peak Partner Rewards Program
description: Xcel Energy's Peak Partner Rewards is a voluntary demand response program for business customers in Colorado that provides financial incentives for reducing electricity usage during peak demand periods. Participants earn monthly capacity credits for committed load reductions of as little as 25 kW, plus additional performance payments when events are called. The program helps manage grid demand primarily during summer months between 12 p.m. and 8 p.m., with events lasting up to four hours. Customers receive at least one hour advance notification by phone, SMS, and email. Year-round credits can add up to thousands of dollars in annual savings, making it an accessible program for small to medium-sized businesses willing to curtail operations during peak periods.

geography.iso_notes: Xcel Energy Colorado operates in the Western Interconnection but is not part of any ISO/RTO. Colorado service territory is not within CAISO, SPP, or other organized markets. Xcel participates in bilateral markets and Western Energy Imbalance Market (WEIM) in some regions.

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Program is designed for business customers (commercial and industrial). Minimum 25 kW interruptible load required. Facilities must be able to reduce demand during summer months (June-September) with as little as one hour notice.

eligibility.front_of_meter_notes: Peak Partner Rewards is a behind-the-meter program for business customer load curtailment. For behind-the-meter battery storage, see separate Xcel Energy Renewable Battery Connect program (residential/business, $350-800/kW rebate plus $100/year for 5 years, 60% storage access up to 60 times/year).
eligibility.aggregator_notes: Direct participation available for individual business customers. For battery aggregation opportunities, contact Xcel Energy account manager.

notification.notification_notes: Participating customers are notified at least one hour prior to each event. Notifications include event start time, expected duration, and end time. Peak events can occur at any time throughout the year but are most likely on weekdays during summer months (June-September) between 12 p.m. and 8 p.m.

capacity_rate.notes: Monthly capacity credit of $2/kW-month paid for committed load reduction capacity. Paid year-round based on nominated curtailable load. Credits applied to monthly electricity bills. Year-round credits often add up to thousands of dollars in annual savings.

performance_rate.calculation_method: Performance payment calculated based on actual energy reduction (kWh) during each event multiplied by $0.70/kWh. Actual reduction measured against baseline. Some sources cite $1.35/kWh as additional event payment rate.
performance_rate.notes: Event performance incentive of $0.70/kWh for actual energy reduction during curtailment events. One source mentions additional $1.35/kWh payment - may represent total performance rate or bonus under certain conditions.

performance_rate_alternative.source_note: One source cited $1.35/kWh as additional payment during curtailment events. Relationship to $0.70/kWh rate unclear - may be cumulative, may apply under different conditions, or one value may be outdated. Recommend verification with Xcel Energy.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: No explicit penalty structure documented in available sources. Program is voluntary and incentive-based. Minimum performance requirements for receiving capacity payments not specified in public documentation.

payment_structure.payment_calculation_notes: Capacity payments based on committed curtailable load (kW) multiplied by $2/kW-month, paid year-round. Performance payments calculated per event based on actual kWh reduced during event. Baseline methodology not specified in public documentation. Credits applied to monthly electricity bills.

seasons.event_frequency_notes: Events most likely during summer months (June-September). Some sources indicate enrolled capacity maintained June-September specifically. Events occur year-round but concentrated in summer.

seasons.max_hours_calculation: 15 events Ã— 4 hours maximum = 60 hours maximum per year
seasons.event_limit_notes: Peak events can be called up to 15 times per year, once per day maximum, with events lasting up to 4 hours each. Capacity payments made year-round.

call_windows.notes: Events most likely to occur on weekdays during summer months between 12 p.m. and 8 p.m. Mountain Time. One source specifies events between 2-6 PM (1-4 hour duration), suggesting core peak window may be narrower during actual event calls.
Peak events can occur at any time throughout the year but are most likely on weekdays during summer afternoon/evening hours (12 PM - 8 PM). Events typically called during high demand periods.

event_parameters.response_time_notes: Minimum one hour advance notification before event start
event_parameters.event_duration_notes: Events last up to four hours. One source specifies events between one and four hours, between 2-6 PM on weekdays.

event_triggers.load_threshold: too much strain on the electric grid
event_triggers.trigger_description: Peak events are called when there is too much strain on the electric grid, typically on hot summer days when electricity demand is high due to air conditioning and cooling loads. Events help ensure the electric grid continues to run smoothly during periods of peak demand. Most likely to occur during summer months (June-September) on weekday afternoons/evenings.

nomination_bidding.nomination_process: Customers fill out the Peak Partner Rewards Agreement PDF and submit to their Xcel Energy account manager or the Business Solutions Center at EnergyEfficiency@xcelenergy.com. Agreement specifies committed curtailable load capacity (minimum 25 kW).

enrollment_period.notes: Enrollment appears to be ongoing throughout the year. Contact Xcel Energy account manager or Business Solutions Center (EnergyEfficiency@xcelenergy.com) to enroll.

performance_measurement.verification_method: Actual energy reduction measured via customer meter data compared to baseline
performance_measurement.minimum_performance_notes: Minimum performance requirements not specified in public documentation. Recommend clarification with Xcel Energy on performance measurement and verification procedures.

special_attributes: accessible to small businesses (25 kW minimum)

Financial incentives for peak demand reduction at commercial and industrial facilities that can reduce load by 50 kW or more during peak periods, primarily summer (June-September)
Opportunity for customers with at least 500 kW of peak load during summer months (June-September) available for service interruption by Xcel

Behind-the-meter residential/business battery storage rebate and demand response program. $350-800/kW AC rebate plus $100/year for 5 years. Xcel accesses up to 60% of stored energy, up to 60 times per year during peak demand.

Program documentation confirms events occur primarily on hot summer weekdays but does not provide specific historical event data.

integration_metadata.optimizer_notes: Program structure is well-suited for battery optimization with accessible 25 kW minimum capacity. Short notification period (1 hour minimum) requires responsive dispatch capability but is manageable for automated battery systems. Predictable call windows (most likely 12-8 PM weekdays June-September) allow for strategic state-of-charge management. Limited event frequency (max 15 per year, 1 per day) and reasonable duration (1-4 hours) fit well within typical battery operational parameters. Strong financial incentives: $2/kW-month capacity payment provides year-round revenue stream ($24/kW-year = $600/year for 25 kW minimum), plus $0.70-1.35/kWh performance payments during events. However, 1-hour notice period is shorter than many DR programs and may limit ability to optimize pre-event charging from lowest-cost energy sources.
integration_metadata.api_notes: API availability for automated dispatch not documented in public sources. Contact Xcel Energy Business Solutions Center (EnergyEfficiency@xcelenergy.com) for technical integration requirements and notification delivery methods suitable for automated systems.
integration_metadata.api_contact: EnergyEfficiency@xcelenergy.com or Xcel Energy account manager
integration_metadata.data_quality_explanation: Moderate quality data available from multiple sources confirming core program parameters: $2/kW-month capacity payment, minimum 25 kW, 15 events/year maximum, 1-hour notice, 1-4 hour duration, primary activity June-September weekday afternoons. Good coverage of eligibility and enrollment process. Significant data gaps: performance payment rate unclear ($0.70/kWh vs $1.35/kWh - conflicting sources), baseline calculation methodology not specified, performance measurement/verification procedures not detailed, penalty structure not documented, exact call window times have some variability in sources (12-8 PM vs 2-6 PM), event triggers described qualitatively only. Historical event data not publicly available. Official PDF documents (info sheet, FAQ, bonus sheet) could not be accessed/parsed, so relied on secondary sources and web search summaries. Recommend direct contact with Xcel Energy for authoritative program details and enrollment agreement terms.
integration_metadata.notes: Xcel Energy serves Colorado as Public Service Company of Colorado, a vertically-integrated utility with local generation and transmission control. Not part of any ISO/RTO (CAISO, SPP, MISO). Participates in Western EIM for some balancing. Peak Partner Rewards is positioned as entry-level business DR program (25 kW minimum), with larger programs available for 50 kW (Electric Rate Savings) and 500 kW (Peak Day Partners, Schedule 60). Separate Renewable Battery Connect program available for behind-the-meter battery storage with upfront rebates and ongoing VPP-style dispatch. Program appears active and well-established based on multiple current references and dedicated program pages.

research_summary.researcher_notes: Comprehensive research conducted across Xcel Energy official website, U.S. Department of Energy FEMP database, Colorado Public Utilities Commission resources, and energy industry sources. Peak Partner Rewards is confirmed as an active business demand response program in Colorado with accessible 25 kW minimum capacity, making it suitable for small to medium commercial customers and behind-the-meter battery storage systems. Core program structure is well-documented: $2/kW-month year-round capacity payments ($24/kW-year), plus event performance payments ($0.70-1.35/kWh range), 1-hour minimum advance notice, 1-4 hour event duration, maximum 15 events per year, primarily weekday afternoons June-September. Program is part of Xcel Energy's broader portfolio of business DR programs with tiers at 25 kW (Peak Partner), 50 kW (Electric Rate Savings), and 500 kW (Peak Day Partners, Schedule 60). Major data gap: official program documents (PDF info sheets, FAQ, bonus structure) could not be accessed/parsed, requiring reliance on secondary sources. Performance payment rate has conflicting values requiring verification. Baseline methodology and M&V procedures not publicly documented. No historical event data available. Recommend direct contact with Xcel Energy Business Solutions Center for enrollment agreement, technical requirements, and authoritative program details.
research_summary.verification_status: All data points extracted from official or authoritative sources (Xcel Energy website, U.S. DOE, utility industry databases). No data invented or estimated. Fields marked as null or 'not specified' represent genuine gaps in publicly available documentation. Conflicting data points flagged with multiple source citations for user verification.

research_summary.confidence_explanation: Moderate-high confidence in core program parameters (capacity payment rate, minimum capacity, event frequency/duration, notification period, general seasonal pattern) due to confirmation across multiple independent sources including U.S. DOE FEMP database and Xcel Energy official website. Lower confidence in: (1) exact performance payment rate due to conflicting sources, (2) baseline and M&V procedures due to lack of public documentation, (3) penalty structure due to no information available, (4) exact call window timing due to minor source variations. Inability to access official PDF program documents directly limits confidence - relied on secondary sources and web summaries. Overall program structure and financial incentives appear reliable, but operational details require direct verification with Xcel Energy for optimization planning and enrollment.
